title: Linking Data, Services, and Human Know-How

author: Paolo Pareti, School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh

segmentation: Hello everyone, I'm Paolo Peretti and today I want to tell you about human, know how knowledge on how to do tasks, activities and how this can fit with the semantic web.
Pulling data, so if you ask an intelligent system what is the population of the capital of NZ?
Chances are you will get now the correct result.
You wouldn't be too surprised and this result comes from a lot of knowledge about populations, about capitals and countries.
This is all good, but then what happen?
If you ask, for example, what is the relation between soap and meat?
So imagine it's a very nice sunny day and you're going to the beach for a barbeque.
You're going to cook raw meat and someone could suggest that to cook.
Raw meat maybe could be useful to wash your hands at some point and to wash your hands.
You might need soap, so this is a functional connection between these two objects, but without knowledge about these activities, you wouldn't actually get this sort of answers from.
System nowadays.
There is a lot of.
Know how on the web exactly the things I just told you are already written on.
Instruction manuals on the web.
There is a lot of human know how, but this knowledge is not accessible by machines.
For example, there are a lot of how to articles like from wikiHow, Snapguide.
Companies have a lot of instructions written like standard operating procedures or more informal.
Procedures.
There are instructional videos, so the formats vary a lot.
There are even some structured sources of know how like API's that can provide you some information about recipes.
But how do we get all of this distributed sources unstructured into one system that can actually make sense out of this?
Well, since we're here, you might guess my solution to this would be linked data and semantic web tech.
Allergies.
The first big problem is how?
How do we get from these unstructured sources to the actual structural representation, which is one of the most common bottlenecks.
Well, this really depends on what format of data you're working with.
If you are talking about.
Completely unstructured text.
There is research about a natural language processing and machine learning to extract information from it.
If it's from pictures and videos, there's image processing.

If you have execution logs of what people did, you could try to detect what process they were following, but what we want to do here is not to find a general solution to everything will be quite hard, but it's what we want to do is to show you that.
It is possible for a large class of resources which is actually very common, which is semi structured semi structured resources.
For example, wikiHow articles have very structured.
Format for example like the one we see here.
For example, a list of steps, at least the requirements you can sort of see how you can go from.
This representation to a graph representation quite straightforwardly, without even requiring natural language processing.
At this stage.
No particularly difficult analysis, and the big advantage of this is that the representation you have also Maps back to something that is human readable, which is not true for other approaches.
The other things would need to develop to be developed in that case.
So this is what we did.
And we did it for two very large websites, wikiHow and SNAP guide.
And in the end we ended up with very large data set with over 200,000 procedures about human activities from most domains.
If you're familiar from wikiHow, you know that there are things like recipes, financial advice, do-it-yourself sort of instructions.
So a lot of varieties in there and the website.
Down there points to the data set.
If you are interested, you can download it an.
We did.
So far I haven't talked about why Link data is important.

You could do the same thing with any representation But link data here is very important because all of these sources are distributed and there are relations between different sets of instructions, instructions, and maybe other datasets like DB pedia.
And if you don't use your eyes and semantic links.
Well, it's much harder than.
So we looked at automatic ways to Interlink resources.
We found links of this kind, so for example from.
One of the step of a procedure to another procedure that explains how to do that step.
So this is a semantic link between 2:00.
Subgraphs, but is not a classic owl.
Same as link.
There are a lot of semantic links that you could find between procedure.
Resources.
You could also find more traditional.
Sort of type links.
For example, in this case, by disambiguating two entities to DB pedia.

You can find out an input output relation between the two sets of resources, so this is to give an idea of the kind of links that were discovered, and then we evaluate the quality of these links compared to the ones that wikiHow Community created.
And it turns out that such links can be created fairly well.
In fact, more precisely than with more precision than wikiHow Community funding.
More links with better coverage, and probably most people here would agree that a semantic link is more meaningful than normal HTML links, so that's an added bonus.
And in the same way, you can also capture knowledge about execution of tasks.
There are lots of systems where you can collaborate with other people, for example following todo lists an.
Often these systems work by checking some items on the list to declare them complete an you can have these represent as linked data and connected to the graph representation that you saw before.
So you can say someone did the first step, but the second step of this procedure has not been done yet.
So you can also map between execution knowledge and know how.
But So what do we do with this knowledge?
Can we actually achieve?
Better integration between human.
And machine.
Efforts in completing a task.
So what I'm proposing here is link data as middle layer to connect humans and machines.
In a way that it captures both the know how and execution of both humans and machine and that both both parties can access.
So what we?
Don't want is webware know how is essentially just in human readable documents so that humans can look at.
Look at them, collaborate with other humans.
But machines have no idea how to support.
Human execution, so every time something needs to be done with the machine, the human has to go and find an appropriate system.
An go through the interface, find a way of using it.
At the same time, we don't want simply to map all this knowledge into a database, process it so that machines can do computation on that.
Maybe try to automate it, but with no feedback loop to the humans again.
In fact, this is targeted to class of problems which are called human computation problems where the task cannot be completely automated but at the same time it is inefficient.
To be completed just by just by humans.
So what we want.
And.

Is essentially to use Link data as a middle ground between humans and machines, something that can easily representation that can be easily mapped from how humans normally write instructions, how they interact with systems too.
Say that they've done something that they want to do something.
And at the same time, this knowledge is also accessible by machines which can see what the humans are doing suggests maybe relevant information, or if something can be automated.
Maybe the machine can do it for you.
So.

Add the assumption that we tried to Weld a prothesis that we tried to bring evidence forward to is that humans can actually write instructions an sort of way, upload their know how in the web in a way that can be not only translated into linked data, but also it's at the level of abstraction that can be connected with machine functionalities.
So if you think about the machine.
I asked too.
Prepare recipe for you.

Maybe it's a bit hard, but for some specific domains there is quite a bit of research on trying to connect human instructions to automatable functions as as you might expect, this is usually related to computers, so things like sending emails, modifying files.
Changing some settings in an operating system.
These are all things that machine could do automatically.
If it knew you wanted to do it.
So we did a small experiment to see how this would work.
And.
The setting is this one, there is.
Business An employee is receiving some data in this format, so lines of tax where you basically have a citian wiki page, Wikipedia page of a city.
But then the task of this employee is to transform it to a different format where some of the symbols around the string has changed and now the Wikipedia page has changed.
The official homepage of a city.
Now, if you have only a few of those, you could do it manually.
If you have a lot, having machine automation would be quite useful.
So if you're a programmer, you could write a script to do this.
Maybe it's not so easy going from the Wikipedia page with City to official homepage of the city, but there is such information on the pedia.
It would still be possible, but if you're not a programmer like in the problem describing.
There is really no straightforward way to explain these tasks to a machine so that it will provide support when needed.
But using this system we tried to solve this problem.
And what we did is we asked through the platform Crowdflower we crowdsourced solutions on how to.
Perform this this set of operations and this is an example, so we ask people to write step by step instructions.
So with a little bit of structure there not completely open text.
But then most people manage to write something like this is a real example.
It was crowd sourced and you can see how the 1st and the third step.
For example removing 2 characters from the string of text, is something a machine could easily perform automatically.
So now we wanted to see can humans also connect these to the functionalities that are required?
So we still crowdsourcing.

We asked workers to tell us whether some functionalities were related to a step, if they could achieve the whole step or only part of the step maybe, or if they were completely unrelated and we had a system that knew about these functionalities and knew how to implement them.
So these functionalities are identified by a UI.
And people could check what they thought was the correct answer.
And sometimes we also asked some additional questions like which is the correct character that needs to be deleted.
For example from this string.

An in the end we analyze the results and at least for this simple scenario, it's not the whole of know how clearly, but it seems like in some situation this could work quite well, so the precision recall are very high in more than.

What we wanted, which was to have the majority of people being able to do this because if more than half of the test subjects can actually choose the right answer, you could simply take the majority and crowd source correct answers for these sort of.
Questions.
So what we ended up now is with.
Essentially need data about this task, which is connected to a human readable representation, but at the same time also connected with machine functionalities.
And now that you have this link data.
You can visualize it to the user, so user now can see through an interface.
Essentially what he wrote before, plus the links that were created, and they can also decide to start an execution of this task.
Pressing one of the buttons above.
Anne.
What happens then is the user is now.
We can now see the execution of the tasks, so a bit like checklist.

You can see the things that have been done, the things that have not been done yet, so you can imagine that the first requirement which is you need to find the first string of text to actually modify, is something the machine cannot automate.
So this is something of the human would have done.
But then, maybe after this has been done, the first step could be automated.
Well, in this case is automated by the machine automatically and this system is all generated from link data.
Then maybe if the machine does not know how to do the second step, it would stop.
It would ask the IT would wait until the human actually does it, and as soon as the human is done, the second step if he knows it can do the third step.
You would also do that automatically and the whole procedure will be complete.
So in this specific example, all the three steps would be automatable.
But you can imagine if you if the machine does not know how to do the second step, how this can interleave human and machine actions.
So.

The general idea that motivates this project is essentially to take know how from the web and also knowledge from about the execution of task when they are executed from distributed sources and using Link data to be able to integrate them all together in a single place and at the level of abstraction that both humans and machines can understand.
So humans should be able to look at these resources an understand a man if necessary, just do everything as they were used to.
To do, but then the machine could also understand from this knowledge and help the user if.
There's something that they can do or propose.
Some links propose some related resources.
And this is the direction that we're moving forward.
Thank you very much.
